Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 01:46PM brca1953 wrote: I too have had frozen shoulder issues.  You need to see a Dr. and try PT.  I ended up having surgery but I think if I'd tried PT first maybe I could have avoided the surgery.  It is painful though so you can also try ice and/or heat, whatever helps the most.  And keep moving your arm/shoulder.  It took about 18 months for me to totally recover. Jo
Posts.Title: Frozen Shoulder stacey2275 brca1953

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 03:45PM brca1953 wrote: My PBM is to be scheduled for end of March and my surgery and PT for frozen shoulder issues was about 6 years ago so I'd had no lymph nodes removed.  So Stacy I'd definately follow Dr.'s orders but I would not ignore it hoping it would go away.  Jo
Posts.Title: Frozen Shoulder stacey2275 brca1953

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 03:48PM - edited Sep 18, 2010 03:50PM by brca1953 Yes, you need to let your Dr. know so that in the future extra care can be taken in exams.  You need to have mammogram and exam annually.  At 57 I just found out I am BRCA2, not surprising because of extensive family breast/ovarian cancer history.  My mother died when she was 48 and I was in my 20's.  I have been vigilent since that time.  My sister was just dx with bc so I decided to take the genetic test.  Once I found out I was BRCA2 I had my daughter who is expecting her first next January let her Dr. know.  She will need to be extra attentive in the future but I'm not suggesting she be tested yet.  It's tough to decide what to do but after talking to 2 breast specialist and a genetic counselor I have made the decision to have a PBM soon, tentatively scheduled for end of Nov.  I want those grandkids to know me as my kids did not get to know their Grandmother.   Jo
Posts.Title: Am I "high risk"? Nyx Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 08:20AM brca1953 wrote: my experience has been like somanywomen's.  When they put the iv in you can ask for something to calm your nerves while you wait.  Close to the time of surgery the anesthesiogist will come in to talk to you usually, you'll have more pleasant conversation with the nurses/aids as you're being wheeled down the hall and then in the operating room there will be a bit more small talk and you'll go to sleep quickly and wake up fine later on.  They'll have you medicated so you should wake up with no pain.  You'll sort of doze off and on as you gradually become more awake.  If you're cold they'll give you a warm blanket.  This part will not be that bad and most likely nothing to worry about unless there are risk factors for the anesthesia which you Dr. will discuss with you before hand.  Will be send good thoughts your way between now and Dec. 2 .. jo
Posts.Title: Risk of anesthesia -mastectomy Polyana mawhinney

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 10:24PM brca1953 wrote: Hi! A_Pallens, I've stopped telling myself that I'm having my boobs cut off which is the way I felt about it at first. I'm now trying to just say to myself that I'm "having breast tissue removed".  It sounds a bit gentler to me, who is someone who can't even watch while getting a shot!  At first I would visualize in vivid detail "having my boobs cut off" but I've been able to stop doing that.  In fact today after an older woman from church was dumbfounded when I told her I was having a mx without having cancer I've almost decided to just start saying I'm having breast augmentation!  Maybe people can understand that better!  I'm hoping that looking at myself and at the drains does not gross me out too much.  Or that I get over it pretty quick.  Anyone else out there worried about seeing their chest after surgery beside me?  Jo
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 01:29AM brca1953 wrote: ForMyBoys .. we'll be having surgery on the same day.  My biggest motivating factor is my daugher.  I DO NOT want her to have to go thru what I did in losing my mother to breast cancer 30 years ago.  She just had her first child and I had just had my first child when my mother was dx with bc.  She died before my daughter was even born.  I took me several years to come to grips with my mother's death and I don't want my DD to have to go through that.  I'll be think of you and praying all goes smoothly.  Jo

Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 10:05PM brca1953 wrote: I picked up the camisoles that the Dr. ordered at the hospital today and pre-registered then got some zip up sweatshirts and other supplies before my last therapy visit until sometime after surgery.  I've not been sleeping well because I wake up at night thinking of things I need to do.  The therapist suggested keeping a notepad on the night stand so I can write it down and then forget about it until morning.  I think I'll try that tonight.  I guess I shouldn't complain though because this is better than being kept awake by pain.   Jules, I hope you are starting to feel better.  Jo
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 05:54PM brca1953 wrote: It's been 6 days since PBM now.  When I went in for post-op visit yesterday they took out both drains since they'd never gotten over 25cc in 1 day.  I feel lucky about that and it was great to get the dressing off too.  I can't shower until tomorrow though and I feel itchy so hope the shower fixes that.  The pain of removing the drains wasn't too bad.  Boobs look awful but I was able to handle it.  I don't know how much saline was put into the TE's but I don't think it was a lot as I seem flat.  I suppose Dr. will do a fill when I go back 3/28.  The pain level is less than I expected but moving my arms hurts way more than I expected.  I've been sleeping a lot but I need to start doing a bit.  I don't worry about overdoing it because the pain of movement will keep me in line.  I hope all you other March ladies are doing good.  Jo

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 05:02PM - edited Sep 18, 2010 05:03PM by brca1953 Will be having PBM, tentativly scheduled for Nov. 30th.  The thing that I FEAR most is the drains too.  My sister was dx in May and had surguery, I was horrified by the drains.  I do not remember them when our mother had mast in '79 but maybe women stayed in the hospital longer.  What are good drain hiding tops to wear?  I absolutely DO NOT want my daughter to see them.  I don't even know if I can handle seeing them.  Jo (BRCA2)
